POINT SOURCE POINT LENS (PSPL) MODELS¶

PSPL User Classes¶

class model.PSPL_PhotAstrom_noPar_Param1(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: model.PSPL_PhotAstrom, model.PSPL_noParallax, model.PSPL_PhotAstromParam1

An abstract class that all Param classes should sub-class. This serves as a reminder for the class variables that MUST be set.

Methods

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, …)

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will be 2 times this value frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

get_amplification(t)

noParallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t.

get_astrometry(t_obs[, ast_filt_idx])

noParallax: Position of the observed source position in arcsec.

get_astrometry_unlensed(t_obs)

noParallax: Get the astrometry of the source if the lens didn’t exist.

get_centroid_shift(t)

noParallax: Get the centroid shift (in mas) for a list of observation times (in MJD).

get_lens_astrometry(t_obs)

Equation of motion for just the foreground lens.

get_resolved_amplification(t)

Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t for both the plus and minus images.

get_resolved_astrometry(t_obs)

Get the x, y astrometry for each of the two source images, which we label plus and minus.

calc_piE_ecliptic

get_chi2_astrometry

get_chi2_photometry

get_lnL_constant

get_photometry

get_resolved_shift

log_likely_astrometry

log_likely_astrometry_each

log_likely_photometry

log_likely_photometry_each
animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, size, zoom, astrometry)¶

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot

e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE

time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will

be 2 times this value

frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

get_amplification(t)¶

noParallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t.

get_astrometry(t_obs, ast_filt_idx=0)¶

noParallax: Position of the observed source position in arcsec.

get_astrometry_unlensed(t_obs)¶

noParallax: Get the astrometry of the source if the lens didn’t exist.

get_centroid_shift(t)¶

noParallax: Get the centroid shift (in mas) for a list of observation times (in MJD).

get_lens_astrometry(t_obs)¶

Equation of motion for just the foreground lens.

get_resolved_amplification(t)¶

Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t for both the plus and minus images.

get_resolved_astrometry(t_obs)¶

Get the x, y astrometry for each of the two source images, which we label plus and minus.

Returns
[xS_plus, xS_minus]list of numpy arrays

xS_plus is the vector position of the plus image in arcsec xS_minus is the vector position of the plus image in arcsec

class model.PSPL_PhotAstrom_Par_Param1(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: model.PSPL_PhotAstrom, model.PSPL_Parallax, model.PSPL_PhotAstromParam1

An abstract class that all Param classes should sub-class. This serves as a reminder for the class variables that MUST be set.

Methods

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, …)

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will be 2 times this value frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

calc_piE_ecliptic()

Parallax: Get piE_ecliptic

Parallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t.

Parallax: Get the centroid shift (in mas) for a list of observation times (in MJD).

get_lens_astrometry(t_obs)

Parallax: Get lens astrometry

get_resolved_amplification(t)

Parallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t for both the plus and minus images.

get_resolved_astrometry(t_obs)

Parallax: Get the x, y astrometry for each of the two source images, which we label plus and minus.

Parallax: Get resolved shift

log_likely_photometry

log_likely_photometry_each

start
animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, size, zoom, astrometry)¶

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot

e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE

time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will

be 2 times this value

frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

calc_piE_ecliptic()¶

Parallax: Get piE_ecliptic

get_amplification(t)¶

Parallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t.

get_astrometry(t_obs, ast_filt_idx=0)¶

Parallax: Get astrometry

get_astrometry_unlensed(t_obs)¶

Get the astrometry of the source if the lens didn’t exist.

get_centroid_shift(t, ast_filt_idx=0)¶

Parallax: Get the centroid shift (in mas) for a list of observation times (in MJD).

get_lens_astrometry(t_obs)¶

Parallax: Get lens astrometry

get_resolved_amplification(t)¶

Parallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t for both the plus and minus images.

get_resolved_astrometry(t_obs)¶

Parallax: Get the x, y astrometry for each of the two source images, which we label plus and minus.

Returns
[xS_plus, xS_minus]list of numpy arrays

xS_plus is the vector position of the plus image. xS_minus is the vector position of the plus image.

get_resolved_shift(t_obs)¶

Parallax: Get resolved shift

class model.PSPL_PhotAstrom_Par_Param2(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: model.PSPL_PhotAstrom, model.PSPL_Parallax, model.PSPL_PhotAstromParam2

An abstract class that all Param classes should sub-class. This serves as a reminder for the class variables that MUST be set.

Methods

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, …)

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will be 2 times this value frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, size, zoom, astrometry)¶

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot

e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE

time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will

be 2 times this value

frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

xS_plus is the vector position of the plus image. xS_minus is the vector position of the plus image.

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, size, zoom, astrometry)¶

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot

e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE

time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will

be 2 times this value

frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

noParallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t.

Returns
[xS_plus, xS_minus]list of numpy arrays

xS_plus is the vector position of the plus image in arcsec xS_minus is the vector position of the plus image in arcsec

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, size, zoom, astrometry)¶

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot

e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE

time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will

be 2 times this value

frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

class model.PSPL_Astrom_Par_Param4(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: model.PSPL_Astrom, model.PSPL_Parallax, model.PSPL_AstromParam4

An abstract class that all Param classes should sub-class. This serves as a reminder for the class variables that MUST be set.

Methods

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, …)

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will be 2 times this value frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

Parallax: Get lens astrometry

get_resolved_amplification(t)

Parallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t for both the plus and minus images.

get_resolved_astrometry(t_obs)

Parallax: Get the x, y astrometry for each of the two source images, which we label plus and minus.

get_resolved_shift(t_obs)

Parallax: Get resolved shift

get_chi2_astrometry

get_chi2_photometry

get_lnL_constant

get_photometry

log_likely_astrometry

log_likely_astrometry_each

log_likely_photometry

log_likely_photometry_each

start
animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, size, zoom, astrometry)¶

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot

e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE

time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will

be 2 times this value

frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

calc_piE_ecliptic()¶

Parallax: Get piE_ecliptic

get_amplification(t)¶

Parallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t.

get_astrometry(t_obs, ast_filt_idx=0)¶

Parallax: Get astrometry

get_astrometry_unlensed(t_obs)¶

Get the astrometry of the source if the lens didn’t exist.

get_centroid_shift(t, ast_filt_idx=0)¶

Parallax: Get the centroid shift (in mas) for a list of observation times (in MJD).

get_lens_astrometry(t_obs)¶

Parallax: Get lens astrometry

get_resolved_amplification(t)¶

Parallax: Get the photometric amplification term at a set of times, t for both the plus and minus images.

get_resolved_astrometry(t_obs)¶

Parallax: Get the x, y astrometry for each of the two source images, which we label plus and minus.

Returns
[xS_plus, xS_minus]list of numpy arrays

xS_plus is the vector position of the plus image. xS_minus is the vector position of the plus image.

get_resolved_shift(t_obs)¶

Parallax: Get resolved shift

class model.PSPL_Astrom_Par_Param3(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: model.PSPL_Astrom, model.PSPL_Parallax, model.PSPL_AstromParam3

An abstract class that all Param classes should sub-class. This serves as a reminder for the class variables that MUST be set.

Methods

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, …)

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will be 2 times this value frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction

animate(tE, time_steps, frame_time, name, size, zoom, astrometry)¶

This function takes the PSPL and makes an animation, the input variables are as follows tE = number of einstein crossings times before/after the peak you want the animation to plot

e.g tE = 2 => graph will go from -2 tE to 2 tE

time_steps = number of time steps before/after peak, so total number of time steps will

be 2 times this value

frame_time = times in ms of each frame in the animation name = string, the animation will be saved as name.html size = [horizontal, vertical] cm’s zoom = # of einstein radii plotted in vertical direction
